title: 112_hr6040
content: The Act is titled the "Continued Free Association with Palau Act of 2012" and includes an amendment regarding a review agreement for the 15th anniversary of the Compact. The "Continued Free Association with Palau Act of 2012" approves the Agreement between the United States and the Republic of Palau, with exceptions and funding provisions for infrastructure maintenance and a fiscal consolidation fund. The Agreement between the United States and the Republic of Palau includes provisions for funding in fiscal years 2011 through 2017, amendments to subsidiary agreements, and the application of related laws. The Agreement between the United States and the Republic of Palau includes provisions for funding in fiscal years 2011 through 2017, amendments to subsidiary agreements, and the application of related laws. Agreements in sections 7 and 8 of the Agreement involve the application of related laws, authorization of appropriations for postal services related to Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Marshall Islands until 2024. The Agreement between the United States and the Republic of Palau includes provisions for funding in fiscal years 2011 through 2017, amendments to subsidiary agreements, and the application of related laws. Appropriations to Federal entities under the Compact of Free Association may be made through fiscal year 2024. The Government of Palau is eligible for certain United States domestic programs. The Congress finds that the Government of Palau is eligible for certain United States domestic programs. The Secretary of the Interior must submit an annual report to specific Congressional committees on the use and effectiveness of assistance provided to Palau under US domestic programs. The Secretary of the Interior must consult with relevant Federal agencies when preparing annual reports on assistance provided to Palau under US domestic programs. SEC. 3. OFFSETS. Repeal of prior authorization for civil administration of Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands and limitation on use of funds for global health programs under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. SEC. 136. LIMITATION ON USE OF FUNDS. None of the funds for global health activities from fiscal year 2012 to 2024 can be used for assistance to China. The total amount for global health activities is reduced by $2,000,000 each fiscal year. This section applies regardless of any other laws enacted after its enactment. ``(a) Limitation.--Funds for climate change activities from 2012 to 2024 cannot be used for assistance to China. The total amount for these activities is reduced by $4,500,000 each fiscal year. This section applies regardless of any other laws enacted after its enactment. (b) Prohibition on Funding for Development Innovation Ventures (DIV) Program.--Funds for the Development Innovation Ventures (DIV) program or any successor program from 2012 to 2013 cannot be used by the United States Agency for International Development.'' The United States Agency for International Development is authorized to use funds for the Development Innovation Ventures (DIV) program or any successor program. The total amount available for the Agency in a fiscal year is reduced by $28,200,000. Additionally, funds under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 cannot be used to provide assistance to Argentina from 2012 to 2024. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 allows funds to be used for assistance to Argentina, with a reduction of $4,500,000 annually until 2024. This provision applies regardless of any other laws enacted later. Additionally, the Act is amended to include provisions related to UNESCO. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 limits the use of funds for assistance to Argentina by reducing $4,500,000 annually until 2024. Additionally, the Act includes provisions related to UNESCO. SEC. 308 further restricts the use of funds. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 limits funds for United States contributions to UNESCO and the United Nations until 2024. The total amount that may be obligated for these contributions is reduced annually by $4,500,000 and $6,811,000 respectively. The total amount available for fiscal year 2012 and onwards is $6,811,000 less than the total amount for that purpose. This subsection applies regardless of any other laws enacted after its enactment.
